article.description: Brandon Foust and Drew Lavender combined for 34 points, and Johnnie Gilbert added 11 to lead Oklahoma past LSU in the NIT.
article.headline: Freshmen Foust, Lavender combine for 34
article.linkText: BCS revenge? Oklahoma puts LSU out of NIT
article.story: BATON ROUGE, La. (AP) -- If the 2004-05 season is a test, the LSU Tigers took their last practice exam on Monday. Darrel Mitchell's 27 points led the Tigers to a 124-78 exhibition victory over Houston Sports Group, but with four days until the season opener, Mitchell said the Tigers still have a lot of work to do. "Rebound, rebound, rebound," Mitchell said. "We did not get enough rebounds against this team. Come SEC time, the players are going to be a whole lot better. We have to continue to improve on the offensive glass. That will help our transition offense a lot." The Tigers open up regular season play Friday when they play host to Tulane in the night-cap of the LSU Louisiana Classic. The first game features Louisiana Tech against Louisiana-Lafayette at 5:30 p.m.. Never trailing in Monday's game, an 18-2 run four minutes into the first half gave the Tigers a 29-11 lead. During the run, the Tiger defense smothered the Houston Sports Group squad, holding them scoreless for 4:04. Houston Sports Group got as close as 41-32 with 5:29 remaining in the first half thanks to a 14-3 run, but LSU quickly put their lead back into double-digits for good with an 11-0 run that gave the Tigers a 52-33 lead. A Tack Minor shot midway through the second half pushed the LSU lead to 85-35. Houston Sports Group would not cut the Tiger lead to fewer than 30 for the remainder of the game. Implementing a new up-tempo offense, LSU head coach John Brady said the team continues to improve and will be ready for the season opener. "If a shot is there, we're going to take it," Brady said. "We want to take that open shot especially on the wing because I feel like Darrel Mitchell is a good shooter, Antonio Hudson is a good shooter, and Regis Koundjia can drive the ball and get fouled. I like that we are taking the ball in transition and getting quality shots at the goal. It just needs to be the hands of our better shooters." Brandon Bass added 20 points for the Tigers to go along with nine rebounds. Minor had 15 points and Hudson added 13 points. Koundjia also had 10 points. Terrance Simmons had 22 points to lead the Houston Sports Group. Willie Byrd added 23 points and Ransom White had 13 and 13 rebounds. Roy Willis also had 10 points.
